title: PCT 02:  The character and knowledge of the Cree
author: Louis Moosomin

sentences.english: Now another, a short one.

sentences.original: nayêstaw wâpiski-wiyâs maci-manitôwah wiya ê-kiskinôhamâkot wêyôtisiwin, êkosi niyanân mâskôc namoya nikiskêyimikonân maci-manitôwah.
sentences.text: nayêstaw wâpiski-wiyâs maci-manitôwa wiya ê-kiskinôhamâkot wêyôtisiwin êkosi niyanân mâskôc namôya nikiskêyimikonân maci-manitôwa
sentences.english: Since only the White Man was taught by the Evil Spirit how to acquire wealth, perhaps we others are not known to the Evil Spirit.
That is why we are poor.
The Cree has much human kindness;

sentences.original: pikw îtê êh-pîhtokêyit ayîsiyiniwah, kiyâm owêyôtisiwah, asamêw; namwâc ahpôh wîhkâc tipahikêhêw.
sentences.text: piko itê ê-pîhtokêyit ayîsiyiniwa kiyâm owêyôtisiwa asamêw namwâc ahpô wîhkâc tipahikêhêw
sentences.english: wherever it be, if a man, and be he a rich man, enters a dwelling, he gives him food; in no case does he make him pay for it.

sentences.original: kiyâm pêyakwâw kita-mîcisot êh-ayât nêhiyaw, êyiwêhk kaskihtâw wîcih-ayîsiyiniwah êh-asamât.
sentences.text: kiyâm pêyakwâw kita-mîcisot ê-ayât nêhiyaw êyiwêhk kaskihtâw wîci-ayîsiyiniwa ê-asamât
sentences.english: Even if the Cree has enough for only a single meal, in some way he manages to give food to his fellow-man.

sentences.original: misiwê ôma askiy nêhiyaw kisêwâtisiwin êh-ayât, êwako piko, kisêwâtisiwin mâwacih êh-ayât, kahkiyaw wîc-âyîsiyiniwah kitimâkêyimêw nêhiyaw.
sentences.text: misiwê ôma askiy nêhiyaw kisêwâtisiwin ê-ayât êwako piko kisêwâtisiwin mâwaci ê-ayât kahkiyaw wîci-ayîsiyiniwa kitimâkêyimêw nêhiyaw
sentences.english: Because, of all this earth, the Cree has most human kindness, because he has more human kindness than all others, the Cree deals kindly with all his fellow-men.

sentences.original: êwak ôhcih pikw îsih kâ-tôtâkot môniyâw-iyiniwa.
sentences.text: êwako ohci piko isi kâ-tôtâkot môniyâw-iyiniwa
sentences.english: That is why the Canadian has been able to do whatever he pleased to him.
Never does the Cree quarrel;
he never fights;
that is as I know it from experience.

sentences.original: namoya nikîh-wanihtânân nêhiyaw ôtah askihk kâ-kîh-isi-pakitiniht.
sentences.text: namôya nikî-wanihtânân nêhiyaw ôta askihk kâ-kî-isi-pakitiniht
sentences.english: We cannot lose the ways with which the Cree was set down here on earth.

sentences.original: êkwah kayâs êsah pêyak nâpêw êh-manitôwit, kîtahtawêh akâmaskîhk ohcih nôcihâw.
sentences.text: êkwa kayâs êsa pêyak nâpêw ê-manitôwit kîtahtawê akâmaskîhk ohci nôcihâw
sentences.english: We are told that in ancient times a certain man who had spirit power was persecuted from across the sea.
The outcome was that he was slain.

sentences.original: êkwah kîtahtawê akâmaskîhk k-âyâcik ayîsiyiniwak, mac-âyîsiyiniwak, pîwâpisk ohcih mânah ayîsiyiniwah êh-osihâcik, ôki wanipahtâkêw-iyiniwak, nîstanaw êhtasicik.
sentences.text: êkwa kîtahtawê akâmaskîhk kâ-ayâcik ayîsiyiniwak maci-ayîsiyiniwak pîwâpisk ohci mâna ayîsiyiniwa ê-osihâcik ôki wanipahtâkêw-iyiniwak nîstanaw êhtasicik
sentences.english: At that time across the sea there were some men, evil men, who made men out of iron, did those persecutors, who were twenty in number.

sentences.original: êkwah kotak awa oskinîkiw kâ-kiskêyihtahk ê-wih-kakwê-nipahiht, wawêyîw;
sentences.text: êkwa kotak awa oskinîkiw kâ-kiskêyihtahk ê-wî-kakwê-nipahiht wawêyîw
sentences.english: Then another man, a youth, who knew that they were going to try to kill him made himself ready;
he  painted himself with clay; he used white clay.
Then he set out;

sentences.original: nipîhk êsah waskic pimohtêw, mistah êh-manitôwit.
sentences.text: nipîhk êsa waskic pimohtêw mistahi ê-manitôwit
sentences.english: he walked over the surface of the water, so great was his spirit power.

sentences.original: êkwah êh-takohtêt êkotê ispimihk, wîkiyihk pakicîw ôhih kâ-wih-kakwê-nipahikot.
sentences.text: êkwa ê-takohtêt êkotê ispimihk wîkiyihk pakicîw ôhi kâ-wî-kakwê-nipahikot
sentences.english: Then, when he arrived up aloft, at the others' dwelling he alighted, at the dwelling of those who were going to try to kill him.
sentences.footnote: LB: The words suggest flying; probably I missed a word that said this; compare the return journey, below.

sentences.english: They saw him; they thought he was an eagle.
“And did I not fear him whom we were going to try to kill?

sentences.original: ahpôh êtokê êwakô! itêw awa kâ-wih-kakwê-nipahât, pîwâpisk ê-macostêkahk ayîsiyiniwah êh-osihât mâna êsah awa mac-âyîsiyiniw.
sentences.text: itêw awa kâ-wî-kakwê-nipahât pîwâpisk ê-macostêhahk ayîsiyiniwa ê-osihât mâna êsa awa maci-ayîsiyiniw
sentences.english: I should not be surprised if this were he!” said the one who was going to try to kill him, putting iron into the hot fire to make a man, as was that evil person's way.

sentences.original: êwak ôhci k-ô-kî-sâkwêyimoyân, ê-sîhkimiyak, itêw êsah;
sentences.english: “This was why I was unwilling, when you urged me,” he told the others;
“No doubt this is he!” he told them.

sentences.original: kiyâm pîhtokêh! kitimâkêyiminân; pê-pîhtwâ! itêw êsah.
sentences.english: “Enter, please! Take pity pn us; come and smoke!” he said to him.
“Ho, I do not wish to smoke.
If so please you, I have come to let you kill me, as you desire,” he told them.
“Oh, it will be impossible to kill you!” he answered him;

sentences.original: êh-ati-itiht, kiyâm kitimâkêyiminân! itik ôhi mac-âyîsiyiniwah;
sentences.english: as he continued to be spoken to in this way, “Please have mercy on us!” he was asked by those evil persons;
“Please let us live!”
No!” he told them; “I have come to let you kill me,” he told them.
“We could not kill you,” they told him.
“Well then, I shall wait until dark.
If you do not intend to kill me, I shall go home as I am.
But I shall be on the lookout for you,” he said.
When darkness came and he went home, he merely flew.

sentences.original: êh-wâpahk ntomêw êsah kahkiyaw kâ-mitêwiyit ayîsiyiniwah, kit-ôsîhtâyit mitêwikamik.
sentences.text: ê-wâpahk nitomêw êsa kahkiyaw kâ-mitêwiyit ayîsiyiniwa kita-osîhtâyit mitêwikamik
sentences.english: On the next day he summoned all the people who took part in the Medicine Ceremony, to have them build a Medicine Lodge.
sentences.footnote: LB: Unless I greatly misjudge, the informant here gives a more favorable account of the Mitewin than could be got from other Sweet-Grass Cree.  He spent some years at an institution for the blind at Winnipeg, where he may have consorted with Ojibwa.

sentences.original: êkwah kiyâm pêyak êh-ayât awiyak maskihkiy, kit-êtohtatâw, êkosi itêw ayîsiyiniwah;
sentences.english: “And please let anyone who has any medicine bring it there,” he told the people;
“Work with zeal; help me in what I am doing;
too many of us are being killed,” he told them;

sentences.original: kisihtâyêkoh ômah k-ôsîhtâyêk mitêwikamik, minah kahkiyaw kîsihtâyêkoh, tahtoh ayîsiyiniwak ka-wih-itohtêcik kîsi-pîhtokêtwâwe, êkospih ka-pê-ntominâwâw, itwêw awa oskinîkiw;
sentences.english: “When you have finished the Medicine Lodge which you are building, and have completed everything, and when as many persons as mean to go there, have entered the lodge, then you are to come and call me,” said that youth;

sentences.original: êkwah pîhtokêyâni, nistikwânihk ka-pakamahonâwâw, itwêw aw ôskinîkiw;
sentences.english: “And when I enter the lodge, you are to strike me on my head,” said the youth;
“I shall be crawling along the ground, when I enter the lodge,” he said;

sentences.original: êkwah mîna nîstanaw atimwak ka-mowâwâwak, itwêw;
sentences.english: “Also, twenty dogs you will eat,” he said;

sentences.original: êkwah kahkiyaw kika-nîmihitonâwâw, itwêw aw ôskinîkiw;
sentences.english: “And all of you will dance,” said the youth;
“And when you have slain me, you will cut me open.
Off to one side you will place it.
Opposite the doorway you will lay blue mats.
And red matting you will lay toward the doorway.
You will make something like a small bed,”

sentences.original: êkotê niyaw iskwâhtêmihk itêy isih, sâkâstênohk êkotêh isi nk-aspiskwêsimon.
sentences.english: “And there my body, towards the doorway, facing the direction whence comes the light of day, I shall lie with my head on it.
And all night you are to dance,” he told them;
“You will eat those dogs.
And two knives will hang by my head as I lie.

sentences.original: kîspin kêkway mihkoh wâpahtamêko, êkosi nika-sâkohâwak akâmaskihk k-âyâcik ayîsiyiniwak, itwêw êsah.
sentences.english: If you see any blood, then I shall be defeating those persons who are across the sea,” he told them.
Accordingly they went and built a Medicine Lodge.

sentences.original: itwêw, kahkiyaw ayîsiyiniwak omaskihkîmiwâwa, mîna mitonih kahkiyaw kîh-mêsci-pîhtokêyêkôh, êkospihk kika-pê-pêkominâwâw.
sentences.english: He said, “When the medicines of all the people are there, and when all of you, completely and to the last one, have entered the lodge, then you will come and wake me by speech.
Meanwhile I wish to sleep,” he said.

sentences.original: tâpwê sôhkih atoskêwak ayîsiyiniwak, mitêwikamik êh-osîhtâcik.
sentences.text: tâpwê sôhki atoskêwak ayîsiyiniwak mitêwikamik ê-osîhtâcik
sentences.english: Accordingly the people worked diligently, building a Medicine Lodge.
Then he was summoned to go there, when it had been completed for him.
When all the people had gone in, he went there.

sentences.original: hâw, niwâhkomâkanitik, kiyâm nipakitêyimâw nikosis, itwêyiwah ôhtâwiya;
sentences.english: “Now then, O my kinsmen, if so please you, I give up my son,” spoke his father;
“As soon as he enters, kill him,” he said.
It was his own father who said, “Kill him!”

sentences.original: ôma k-êsi-sîhkimikoyêk kakwê-tôtamok, itwêyiwa ôhtâwiya, mâka wiya kisêyiniw pêkitêyimât ôh ôkosisah.
sentences.text: itwêyiwa ôhtâwiya mâka wiya kisêyiniw pêkitêyimât ôhi okosisa
sentences.english: “Try to do this in the way that he has bidden you,” said his father, the old man himself thus offering up his son.
As soon as the latter crawled into the lodge, he was struck on the head.
The young men went faithfully to work, slashing him open here at his chest.
Then they laid him down in the way he had bidden them.
They did it all in that way.
“Now then, all of you dance!

sentences.original: êkâ mâh nântaw mêcimwâcih nipahâyêkoh nikosis! itwêw awa kisêyiniw kêsêwâtisit.
sentences.english: Remember that you have not by any means really slain my son!” said the old man, so generous was he.
Accordingly they danced all night.

sentences.original: êh-pêh-wâpaniyik, kîtahtawê kâ-wâpahtahkik mihkoh môkomânihkânihk êh-pahpahkikawiyik.
sentences.text: ê-pê-wâpaniyik kîtahtawê kâ-wâpahtahkik mihko môhkomânihkânihk ê-pahpahkikawiyik
sentences.english: As dawn approached, there at one time they saw blood dripping from the blades of the knives.

sentences.original: êkwah tâpwê cihkêyihtamwak ê-nîmihitocik, nayêstaw atimwah êh-môwâcik.
sentences.text: êkwa tâpwê cîhkêyihtamwak ê-nîmihitocik nayêstaw atimwa ê-môwâcik
sentences.english: Then truly did they put their heart into the dance, and only dogs they ate.

sentences.original: pîsim êh-pê-sâkêwêt, êkoyikohk natawâpênâwâw awa oskinîkiw.
sentences.text: pîsim ê-pê-sâkêwêt êkoyikohk natawâpênawâw awa oskinîkiw
sentences.english: When the sun rose above the horizon, they went to view that youth.
There it was seen by all that he returned to life.

sentences.original: kahkiyaw êsah kî-sâkôcihêw anihih nîstanaw tah ayîsiyiniwah.
sentences.text: kahkiyaw êsa kî-sâkôcihêw anihi nîstanaw ita ayîsiyiniwa
sentences.english: He had overcome all of those twenty persons.
It appears that they had all gone to sleep beyond hope of revival.
sentences.footnote: Perhaps read {okî-nâspitsi-nipahâhtâwâw}: “they had killed him beyond the possibility of revival”.

sentences.english: That is one story;

sentences.original: êkotah ohci namoya êkoyikohk miywâsin mitêwikamik.
sentences.text: êkota ohci namôya êkoyikohk miywâsin mitêwikamik
sentences.english: but since then the Medicine Lodge has not been so good a thing as all that.

sentences.original: kahkiyaw kêkway mac-âyisak ahpôh ayîsiyiniwak kî-nâ-nipahitôwak, maci-maskihkiyah êh-âpacihtâcik, êh-pistispôwihtocik.
sentences.text: kahkiyaw kêkway mac-âyisak ahpô ayîsiyiniwak kî-nâ-nipahitôwak maci-maskihkiya ê-âpacihtâcik ê-piscipôwihtocik
sentences.english: All kinds of evil beings or person have killed one another, by using bad medicines to poison one another.

sentences.original: pikw îsi isi-kaskihtâwak êsi-nisiwanâcihitocik kayâs ayîsiyiniwak.
sentences.text: piko isi isi-kaskihtâwak êsi-nisiwanâcihitocik kayâs ayîsiyiniwak
sentences.english: The old-time people were able to do all manner of things in the way of destroying one another.

sentences.original: êwako wiyawâw ocipwêwak nîkân kâ-kîh-miyikôwisicik mitêwiwin;
sentences.text: êwako wiyawâw ocipwêwak nîkân kâ-kî-miyikôwisicik mitêwiwin
sentences.english: It was the Ojibwa who first were given this Medicine Ceremony by the Higher Powers;
they went into the actual presence of the Spirit of the Mitewin.

sentences.original: êkotah ohcih kahkiyaw kêkway nipîhk k-ôtaskiyit, êyakonik mâmostawêwak kâ-mitêwicik;
sentences.text: êkota ohci kahkiyaw kêkway nipîhk kâ-otaskîyit êyakonik mawimostawêwak kâ-mitêwicik
sentences.english: Since then, those who participate in the Medicine Rite, worship all those beings that have their home in the waters;
they worship also that being who has his home in springs;

sentences.original: mîna tahtoh kêkway kâ-sâkikihk ôtah askîhk, êwakonih kîh-kiskinôhamâkôwisiwak kit-si-mawimostahkik.
sentences.text: mîna tahto kêkway kâ-sâkikihk ôta askîhk êwakoni kî-kiskinôhamâkôwisiwak kita-isi-mawimostahkik
sentences.english: and they were told by the spirits to worship as many things as grow forth out of this earth.

sentences.original: anohc kêyâpic mihcêt kêkway êh-pwâtawihtâcik maskihkîwiyiniwak, kaskihtâwak nêhiyawak omaskihkîmiwâwaw ohci;
sentences.text: anohc kêyâpic mihcêt kêkway ê-pwâtawihtâcik maskihkîwiyiniwak kaskihtâwak nêhiyawak omaskihkîmiwâwa ohci
sentences.english: To this day, many things which the physicians fail of doing, the Cree can do them through their medicines;
what wonder, since the Cree was given medicine by the Higher Powers?

sentences.original: iyikohk êspîhcâk askiy, kahkiyaw kêkway kâ-wâpahtamihk, niyîpihkih kâw-ohpikihk, êspîhcâk askiy, misiwê kih-têpastawân nêhiyaw omaskihkîm.
sentences.text: iyikohk êspîhcâk askiy kahkiyaw kêkway kâ-wâpahtamihk niyîpihki kâ-ohpikihk êspîhcâk askiy misiwê kî-têpastâwân nêhiyaw omaskihkîm
sentences.english: Over all the extent of the earth, everything that is seen growing forth in the summer time, as far as the earth extends, everywhere the medicine of the Cree was placed within his reach.

sentences.original: misiw îtê itâpiyêkoh ka-wâpahtênâwâw nêhiyaw êh-kîh-miyiht wîstah kit-ôhcih-pimâtisit.
sentences.text: misiwê itê itâpiyêko ka-wâpahtênâwâw nêhiyaw ê-kî-miyiht wîsta kita-ohci-pimâtisit
sentences.english: Wherever you may look, you will see that which the Cree, for his part, was given, that he might derive from it his continuance of life.
Also, as half of the gift, he was given bad medicine.
Those same Medicine Dancers were the ones to whom it was taught by the Higher Powers;

sentences.original: kahkiyaw kêkway kî-wîhtamâkôwisiwak kit-si-nanâtawihiwâkêcik, ahpôh nipîhk kahkiyaw kêkway k-ôhpikiniyik, kitâ-pâsahkik kahkiyaw kêkway maskihkiy.
sentences.text: kahkiyaw kêkway kî-wîhtamâkôwisiwak kit-si-nanâtawihiwâkêcik ahpô nipîhk kahkiyaw kêkway kâ-ohpikiniyik kita-pâsahkik kahkiyaw kêkway maskihkiy
sentences.english: they were shown by the spirits every way of doctoring people, all the things, even, which grow in the water, that they might dry all kinds of medicinal herbs.
I tell this because I wish to discourse upon how the Cree lived of old.

sentences.original: nimiywêyihtên mantôw wiyah êh-itêyihtahk, awa nâpêw kâh-pêh-natawêyihtahk nêhiyaw tânisi kâ-k-îsi-pimâtisit.
sentences.text: nimiywêyihtên manitow wiya ê-itêyihtahk awa nâpêw kâ-pê-natawêyihtahk nêhiyaw tânisi kâ-kî-isi-pimâtisit
sentences.english: I am glad that the Lord had it in mind that this man should come here and desire to know how the Cree used to live.

sentences.original: mitonê mâka kahkiyaw miyo-kanâpamikôwisit ayîsiyiniw, êkwah kayâs nik-ayimôtên.
sentences.text: mitoni mâka kahkiyaw miyo-kanâpanikôwisit ayîsiyiniw êkwa kayâs nika-âyimôtên
sentences.english: How well the people of old were taken care of, in everything, by the Powers, of that I shall now speak.
sentences.footnote: CHECK kanapamikowisit - either PCT or lexfile has typo

sentences.english: Originally the Cree had no kind of law;

sentences.original: kipahotôwin nama kêkway; nama kêkway mac-ihtiwin;
sentences.text: kipahotôwin nama kêkway nama kêkway maci-ihtiwin
sentences.english: there was no such thing as imprisonment; no such thing as crime;
people simply used their own considerate judgment.

sentences.original: ayisk nêhiyaw nama kêkway ohci mâyi-tôtam;
sentences.text: ayisk nêhiyaw nama kêkway ohci mâyi-tôtam
sentences.english: For the Cree did not, by his original nature, do wrong;
it is not in the nature of the Cree to do wrong to God.

sentences.original: êkwah nêhiyaw tipiyaw wiya manitôwa kîh-kakêskimik;
sentences.text: êkwa nêhiyaw tipiyaw wiya manitôwa kî-kakêskimik
sentences.english: The Cree was instructed by God himself in person;
that is why the Cree has gentleness.
For he has kindness of heart, since God came and instructed the people.

sentences.original: êkwah mîna piko iskwêwa kîh-nâ-naskowasimik; êkosi kîh-wiyasôwatêw.
sentences.text: êkwa mîna piko iskwêwa kî-nâ-naskwêwasimik êkosi kî-wiyasôwâtêw
sentences.english: At that time only the woman made rejoinders to Him;  therefore He pronounced the law for her.

sentences.original: nama wîhkâc mistahi kita-yâhkastêw kitatoskêwin; osâm kinâ-naskowasimin.
sentences.english: “Never shall your work show great advance; for you have retorted to me.

sentences.original: kiyâm kapê-kîsik atoskêyanih, pêyakwan iyikohk kit-êspîhcipayiw kitatoskêwin, kîh-itêw êsa manitôw.
sentences.english: Let it be that when you work all day, your work will be as far advanced as it was before,” God said to her.
For her alone He decreed ill.
The man stayed still when the Cree was first made.

sentences.original: êkosi êsa kîh-ispayiw, itwêwak kayâs kisêyiniwak, oskac êw-osihât manitôw nêhiyawah.
sentences.text: êkosi êsa kî-ispayiw itwêwak kayâs kisêyiniwak oskac ê-osihât manitôw nêhiyawa
sentences.english: Thus it must have gone, said the old men of yore, when God first made the Cree.
So that is the way it must have happened.

sentences.original: êkotah kî-wîhtamôwêw kahkiyaw kêkway maskihkiyah, mîna mawimoscikêwin kit-âyâyit.
sentences.text: êkota kî-wîhtamawêw kahkiyaw kêkway maskihkiya mîna mawimoscikêwin kita-ayâyit
sentences.english: There He told him every kind of medicine, and the religion he was to have.
And at this point I shall cease to discourse of things concerning  the Lord.
Now I shall tell a sacred story.
And so this is one discourse.
We, too, have a teaching of God.

sentences.original: ayisk namoya niyanân n-ôh-nipahânân manitôw okosisa;
sentences.text: ayisk namôya niyanân n-ôh-nipahânân manitôw okosisa
sentences.english: You see, not we have ever slain God's Son;
that is why the Evil One does not know us.

sentences.original: êwak ôhci êkâ kêkway kaskihtâwin k-ôh-ayâyâhk.
sentences.text: êwako ohci êkâ kêkway kaskihtâwin kâ-ôh-ayâyâhk
sentences.english: And that is why we have no kind of worldly power.
